April 13th
I recieved your cable this morning asking for the source of that runour.
I was unable to wire who the person was who originated the tale but I
shall endevour to find out. Sonny Whitney told it as an amusing funny story- suppos-
sedly to give onea laugh. I did not think that sort of story was a very good 
one to float around]but as 1 told you it was hard to refute not having a 
glimmer of an idea what it was all about. The lord only knows who the story is real
about- probably an other guy whom it happened to,or perhaps its a fabrication
of the mind and has no basis even about an other fellow. I have hover heard 5
of a Legendre being rude 1n.my lifqaand was sure that was no truth in any of it. 1
If I find out who started it shal let yop know. I shall work on Sonny to toll me
He probably will refuse to tell me but I shall ceratinly ask.
I dont believe you should worry about it as I dont believe it was meant as a mal
ioious story. I dont know anyone else who has ever spoken of it, and there was _
only Sonny his wife Eleanor and myself at the time listening. Is n't it amazing
how tw1sted,and redicu1ous,and frightful stor1es.can be concocted whsich have no
foundation whatso ever. I think you should not give it an other thought because
 my fast letter how that Commander Jelky had told me what swell  
reports he had heard about you in the Navy Department and what knockouts you both
must be. I was so proud gf you, and wrote you about it.
I loved your letter this morning mailed the Vth- that arrived so fast too.
Your wonderful description of evening in the tropics, the stlas, the sof air,
the rustling of the plam leaves. My darling 'how love that setting. Howivould love
to be there beside you drinlcrlng it all in, holding; you tight, loving under those stmi
- that moon- those palms. I do love that tropical softness so much- that lovely
picture you describe. I can see it and almost feel it, I know that heavenly
evening when the heat of day is passed and everything; is so still and yet so alive
- its beautiful. The perfect spot for you and me to love in.I do hope we can _
live that sort of thing together some day, and I hope that day is not too far off.
There is nothing; in the world equal to salt water and sunshine. I have always l
loved it more than anything els? and I would love it believe me this second instead
of this city existence, this fi thy Q bldg, the pavements, etc. It is spring
and one realizes how beautiful it would be in the country, instead,,you see a plum
tree in bloom in some ones back yard, a blue bird on a brick wall, yellow dafadils
sprouting; against a i'ence.An effort of grass and flowers to show they are alive
and want to bloom,but somehow all that show of spring life is so restricted, so
puney and pathetic. The trees struggle for life ln a feted City atmosphere of
basses and taxis, cement and brick. It makes one long for open country, rolling
hills, vegetable gardens, woods and fresh air. Well as you say Darling, this _all '_
cant last forever. Someday you and I will breath in the country again. We will swim
in the ocean together, we will lye on sand beaches in the sun, and leave the strife
and pettiness of life behind us. I wish I knew where we will do all this. Have you
decided?
As a bycicled down this morning to the office I passed Col Don- walking. He
asked me how I was comming with the WAACS. I told him I was not elegible as I had
children under 14 -He said he would have this waved and get me in it. God only knows
[End Page 1]

what to do. I think he wants to have me become a WAAS officer. I am not too
sure if this is a correct move or not. I dont know if I could get through
Officers school if I d1d'get sent. I dont know if I have had sufficient education.
I dont know if? uld ast through it or get flunked. I would hate to join and .
find myself only priv t He wants me fo do it up brown and come back here an
officer. He says he wil aarantee that will work for him for the duration and
not for the WAACS That h will have me assigned to O.S.S. and then once in uniform
he can send me anywherelaad that I c an chose where I want t go and he will back
me. They need personal ab cad terribly in our outfit: Somanyspots want and need
workers, that I have a chgce to chose which country prefer. We operate in an
awful lot of countries. e work is d--- interesting and ofcourse doubly so when
in the fieldand not in Washington. I dont know what to do. I cant get over with
out a un1form,and it does not look as though Mrs Hubby was willing to give us a
provurement of officers the way the army does for the men. What do you thinkil
should do?
I wonder if there is going; to be a chance of youvbeing transfered to '
the Atlantic and away from the Pacific- does it seem possible? Gee that would be
wonderful. The .Taps seem to be picking up again out in New Guinea and it looks like
an other big; push out there. Europe is working out so much better. I really believe
North Africa will be over verry soon, its going marvelously now.
I amsending my secretary Miss Pearson and her pal Mrs Baumer to N.Y.C.
this corminpg weekend . hey have never been and are going 'to enjoy it so much. I
have bought them seats to Ethel Merman's show and also for the Circus at Madison
Square ,and I think they will have a swell time. They both work like smoke and are
the most willing pair in the world, good natured and 1ndustious.I am very lucky to
have them. The volume of work increases daily and we all do more than we have ever
done before. Not a minute to breathe or go to the Cafeteria for a cogia cola.
_ I am lunching to-day at a Foxcroft reunion luncheon which I bet will be
funny. I shall finish this letter to you when I come back so 1 can tell you aboutit.
LATER-
' The lunch was most impressive. Held at the Sulgrave Club. There must have
been over I50 alum ae there. Miss Charlotte made a wonderful speach.Mov1ei w
were shown of the girls drilling fn their new tan and green un1forms,and must say
they were just as good as the WAACS and WAVES. Hhss C. brought four gilrs with
her and they sang the1r_marching song,and made speaches,and it was really very
attractivg and festive, and impressive. Marianna Coleman and Betty Iselin were
there so I saw some old Pals I knew among the sea of strange faces. We find that '
so far we'have not a Fbxcrofter in either the WAACS or WAVES. Maybe I shall
be the first. I was told while I was there that the aptitude test they give you
on entering is what decides whether you are eligible for Officers training. You
have to get over so; to be a private and get IIO [percent]marks to be chosen as an officer.
You know me- I am far from smart, my education was lousy,and I could Nbt pass a
thing. That is what frightens me. I should hate to be in as a private for the
duration. You then cant speak to officers and I am told cant live anywhere except
in barracks. I would N't do it if that was to be my fate. Gee really am stick a .
as to what to do. I cant get anywhere but stay in Vasgington if I dont try for
the WAACS. I am_stuiped as to how to decide what to do. Charlie Cheston just called
me this m1nute.he is in the Col's office. He works with us now. He said to sit tight
for a week and he would know alot more about it, and will let me know, so I may
know more later on- next time I write you. Mr Cheston asked about you and Morris
and Armant,and told me he had seen Kathrine a couple of weeks ago. I dont remember
hlmalthough I believe he was up in Maine with us was n't hefor was it Philla? that
we knew him?
All my love goesto you my darling as always, I think of you so much all
the time and wonder where you are and what you are doing at all moments of the
day.
Always- your- Gertie- My love to Morris too.
[End Page 2]
